Accidentally squirts ink on Dolores’s dress, possibly as a reaction but masks it as an accident.
Freezes and is unable to act when Rosalie is applauded and celebrated, showing hesitation.
Urges Rosalie to stop diving to avoid injury, showing concern for her safety despite Rosalie's resistance.
Feels helpless when Rosalie dismisses her concerns and ignores her advice.
Advises Rosalie to stop diving because it's dangerous, showing awareness and concern.
Persists in warning Rosalie despite being dismissed and called sick, demonstrating resolve but ultimately unable to change the situation.
Feels helpless after her warnings are ignored and the situation appears inevitable.
Kisses Richard on the forehead and says 'I love you too, Richard. Thanks for trying.'
Tells Charlie 'Forget it, it'll never work.' after he offers help with her song.
Says 'Thank you' to a man who helps her pick up her suitcase after she drops it.
She kisses Richard on the forehead and expresses gratitude for his effort, showing emotional intelligence and social grace.
Dismisses Charlie's reworked song suggestion with 'Forget it, it'll never work,' showing a lack of openness to feedback or creative flexibility.
Runs away upon seeing people watching her, indicating emotional distress and avoidance rather than confronting the situation.
Despite being nervous and emotional, she manages to get off the bus by herself and politely thanks a stranger for help, showing basic social skills and self-reliance.
Hesitates at the bus door upon arrival, displaying uncertainty or lack of confidence in the moment.
Hugs her grandparents tightly upon arrival, showing openness and affection.
Requests her grandmother teach her to make strudel, indicating trust and a desire for connection.
Sits with Elizabeth, chatting while doing chores, engaging in friendly interaction.
Approaches grandparents and openly shows emotion, hugging them tightly.
Asks Grandma to teach her how to make strudel, showing willingness to learn and engage with others' skills.
Curls up in the back of the car, regressing and behaving like a child.
Sits with Elizabeth learning to knit, showing patience and willingness to acquire new skills.
Shows fear by shivering and placing hand over heart, unable to articulate or manage her fear.
Expresses sorrow that her grandmother had a bad dream about Elizabeth dying
Shares affection for her children and expresses that she misses them
Chooses to honor Elizabeth by deciding to name her daughter after her
Expresses confusion and curiosity about Elizabeth's lack of fear and ideas about time and dreams.
Makes a thoughtful decision to name her daughter after Elizabeth, showing reflection and meaningful choice.
Expresses concern about family drifting apart, mentioning she never sees the cousins anymore.
Hugs Grandma Elizabeth before leaving for the lodge meeting.
Initiates going to the lodge meeting out of curiosity.
Shows curiosity about family gatherings and lodge meetings and takes initiative to attend the lodge meeting.
Engages in lighthearted, somewhat naive conversation without deeper strategic thinking or problem solving in the excerpt.
Nervously clings to Barney's arm when entering the lodge; thanks people who welcome her
Allows Barney to take her jacket without hesitation
Nervously clings to Barney's arm and expresses discomfort about wearing the lodge hat.
Politely acknowledges compliments from other members of the lodge.
Responds respectfully and sincerely to a solemn ritual, participates with a serious and willing attitude.
Accepts the golden cape and takes her place on the throne calmly and cooperatively.
Responds confidently and clearly to Leo Cooper's question, indicating readiness.
Makes a lighthearted comment ('Fasten your seat belts. Here we go.') in a serious ritual context, showing confidence and control of the situation.
Smiles back at Barney's wink during the ritual despite her doubt.
Expresses skepticism about the ritual ('This is never going to work').
Struggles and questions Charlie when he restrains her by covering her mouth.
Sotto voices doubt ('This is never going to work') during a ritual, indicating awareness and critical thinking about the situation.
Struggles when Charlie carries her off, but questions him immediately ('What the hell did you do that for? What are you doing here?'), showing assertiveness and presence of mind.
Refuses to get into the car, asserts her boundaries and challenges Charlie's plans for her life.
Dismisses the threat of being 'vaporized' and calls the people harmless, showing skepticism and critical thinking.
Lets Charlie drag her up a hill despite her resistance, showing some passivity.
Explodes emotionally and criticizes Charlie for making decisions on her behalf, revealing emotional and situational awareness.
Cries and admits to feeling hurt and betrayed, but leans into Charlie and embraces him with sincerity and vulnerability.
Refuses to marry Charlie twice, expressing clear boundaries and self-respect despite emotional pain.
Refuses to marry Charlie twice despite emotional pressure, showing awareness and self-protection.
Struggles emotionally and has difficulty helping Rosalie, indicating some limitation in coping or control.
Composes herself after crying and requests to be taken to her grandparents, demonstrating a degree of emotional regulation and practical decision-making.
Clings emotionally to Charlie despite earlier refusal, indicating vulnerability and possible difficulty in maintaining boundaries.
Leans into Charlie and throws her arms around him, holding on for dear life; looks up at him with foreheads touching.
Responds sincerely and simply to Charlie's tender 'I love you' with 'I know.'
Smiles while watching Charlie's car being struck by lightning; blows a kiss to her grandfather in the crowd.
Expresses love to Charlie, promising to love him for twenty years.
Leaves Charlie despite his pleas and professed love, insisting she has to go now.
Jumps to her feet and races toward the descending kite, takes immediate action to grab the kite's tail and sail away, showing decisiveness and quick response.
Continues to sail away despite Charlie's pleas and the dangerous situation with the kite, demonstrating determination but possibly risking safety.
Speaks affectionately to Charlie despite the stressful hospital situation, showing concern for him.
Questions Charlie about Janet, indicating honesty and openness about her feelings.
Smiles at the book dedication but shakes her head, showing humility.
Admits to having a strange experience going back to high school and spending time with Charlie and friends, showing openness.
Acknowledges Charlie's persistence and finally asks him to hold her, indicating vulnerability and trust.
Tells Charlie she needs some time, setting a clear but gentle boundary.
Questions who the flowers are from, showing awareness and engagement despite being in a hospital bed.
Dismisses the dedication in the book by saying 'It couldn't be me. I hardly knew him.', reflecting modesty or lack of confidence in social connections.
Describes revisiting high school memories and interactions with Charlie with emotional clarity, demonstrating reflective insight.
Tells Charlie she needs some time, establishing boundaries and making a clear request.
Invites Charlie and his kids to dinner and offers to make strudel.
Leans over and kisses Richard sadly on the forehead when saying goodbye.
Admits to feeling like an anachronism, upset parents, and missing her kids, expressing vulnerability.
Invites Charlie to dinner and offers to make strudel, showing social confidence and initiative.
Approaches Richard in the library and states she is leaving, showing decisiveness.
Expresses feelings of being a 'walking anachronism' and describes emotional turmoil, indicating self-doubt and emotional overwhelm.
Admits to breaking up with Charlie and acknowledges taking a big gamble, showing willingness to take risks based on her feelings.
Slams down the book and decisively states she does not want to marry anybody, ending the conversation with Richard.
Clearly recognizes Richard's opportunity to be Valedictorian and tells him he can't follow her, showing awareness of appropriateness and priorities.
